title: 113_hr1199
content: The Act titled "Safe Schools Improvement Act of 2013" is cited in Section 1. Section 2 contains findings related to the Act. Congress finds that bullying and harassment in schools can seriously harm students' physical and psychological health, leading to academic issues such as high dropout rates and absenteeism. These behaviors include physical violence, name-calling, intimidation, social exclusion, and cyberbullying. Students are targeted for bullying and harassment based on various factors like race, gender, and sexual orientation. Schools with anti-bullying policies see increased reporting and teacher intervention, reducing the frequency of incidents. Some experience relational aggression, a form of psychological bullying. Interventions to address bullying and harassment in schools include creating a positive and safe school climate with evidence-based discipline policies like PBIS and restorative practices. 85 percent of Americans support a Federal law to prevent bullying in schools. Students, parents, educators, and policymakers are urging for leadership and action to tackle the national crisis of bullying and harassment. The purpose of the Safe Schools Improvement Act is to address bullying and harassment in public elementary and secondary schools through the implementation of anti-bullying policies. The Safe Schools Improvement Act defines bullying to include cyberbullying and requires states receiving grants to mandate local educational agencies to establish policies preventing severe, persistent, or pervasive conduct that limits a student's participation or creates a hostile educational environment. The Safe Schools Improvement Act mandates policies prohibiting bullying or harassment based on various characteristics, including race, color, national origin, sex, disability, sexual orientation, gender identity, religion, and other defining traits determined by the State or local educational agency. The Safe Schools Improvement Act requires local educational agencies to provide annual notice of prohibited conduct and grievance procedures for complaints, including designated officials and resolution timelines. The Safe Schools Improvement Act mandates collecting accurate data on incidents, promoting positive discipline approaches, and ensuring students are not disproportionately punished. The Safe Schools Improvement Act requires the chief executive officer of a State receiving a grant to submit a biennial report to the Secretary, detailing information reported by local educational agencies and outlining plans to support efforts addressing prohibited conduct. The Secretary must conduct a biennial evaluation of anti-bullying programs in schools, assess their effectiveness, and report findings to the President and Congress. Data on prohibited conduct must be collected from States for analysis. Data on prohibited conduct must be collected from States for analysis, including data submitted under section 4403. The part emphasizes that the obligations under this law do not override existing federal and state nondiscrimination laws, including title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972, section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, and the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990. The part clarifies that it does not change legal standards or impact the rights of individuals under other federal laws protecting freedom of speech and expression. The text outlines that states and local entities can enact laws to prevent bullying or harassment of students as long as they are not inconsistent with the specified regulations in the Safe Schools Improvement section of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965.
